segments.text: That might have been the biggest rumor about any concrete step taken by the U.S.
I think the great disappointment of all the thinking Hungarians was the crisis of the Suez Canal right following on the Hungarian Revolution.

it became obvious to us that in the confusion that the Soviet experienced in this totally unexpected revolution in Hungary, the British and the French took advantage and started the invasion of the Suez Canal.
That was the greatest betrayal of the freedom fight.
because it is manifested to the Hungarians that the West has other priorities than Eastern Europe.
And it has also shown that in the Middle East, even armed intervention for the oil interests of the West is imaginable, but for Eastern Europe, no such risk will be ever taken.
I think I learned about the West quite a bit from that step.
I have not been bitter, nor am I really ultimately bitter today, I think I just developed a healthy amount of cynicism, which I still preserved.
And every thinking person should be realistic about the way oil rules the world.
Okay.
I'd like to talk a little bit about how you came to come to the United States.
Well, my coming to the United States does not parallel the way most of the refugees of 1956 came to this country.
The revolution was followed by an exodus of 200,000 Hungarians, most of them young, and most of them educated to the West.

and the way I considered the West that I have seen, because I myself fled the country on the 21st of November, so less than a month after the revolution, I felt that the West was tremendously helpful, just to say I'm a Hungarian meant in the first few weeks after my departure from Hungary,
a free ticket to any country, and that the US included.
I think the first 50,000 people leaving Hungary virtually had a free choice of choosing any country of immigration.
Such places as Switzerland, which has never had an open immigration policy,
opened its borders for 10,000 Hungarian immigrants.

And of course, the U.S. had dramatically increased its contingent, its quota for Hungarian refugees, so that had I said right upon my arrival to Vienna that I want to go to the U.S., within a week I could have arrived here.
But at that time, I wanted to go to Rome and study, plus I had a brother,

refugee of earlier years living in Vienna and actually running a very good business so I did not even consider coming to the US at that time it was only after finishing my studies in Rome that my order has decided that I should join our foundation in Texas by the way our foundation just came about at the time of the Hungarian Revolution
the monastery in Dallas has just started a few months before the revolution broke out.
In 1955 we came to, our first group came to this place, and it was in 56 that the first wing of the Abbey was opened.
But I came here of course only in 1962, at the time I was already a
westernized after I had lived for six years in Western Europe and got very much acquainted with the other half of the world, which up to that time was completely sealed and unknown to me.
I arrived to the West as coming to a completely different world.
Okay.
In retrospect, what do you see as the accomplishments of the

revolution well the the revolution did not accomplish anything that it was it has set out to accomplish at the same time it has accomplished a lot of things that it did not really intend to immediate success was and that is unfortunately again in was in favor of of other people than than the ones who
fought and died, the immediate success appeared first of all in Western Europe.
The French Communist Party and the Italian Communist Party literally fell apart in the aftermath of the Hungarian Revolution.
The strength of the communist movement in Western Europe was based first of all and most of all on the tremendous brilliance
of the French Communist Party.
The French Communist Party, as people might still recall, included the best minds of the country.
Jean-Paul Sartre himself was a communist, and Jean-Paul Sartre left the Communist Party a few weeks after the Hungarian Revolution.
So, the Communist Party has lost membership and votes
in the decade following the Hungarian Revolution.
As a consequence, what was a danger in the West, namely communist takeover either in Italy or France ceased to exist.
And so that was a, I think, a great service for freedom in Western Europe.
And you might say that on the long run
the communist movement in Western Europe has never recovered from that loss.
It peaked before the Hungarian Revolution and has never reached that same peak.
Maybe in Italy it did, but by the time in Italy it came back again,
with a large number of votes, the communist movement has disassociated itself from Russia.
So, in a sense, that was a deadly loss and defeat for the Western European communist movement.
I think the Hungarians should be proud of having achieved that, without having tried it.
Another thing which Hungary now enjoys to a great extent
is the relaxation of the communist system in Hungary.
That did not take place immediately, but the gulag communism, as we call it now, has been in a way the product of the atmosphere which came about after the revolution.
The Hungarian

leaders, the puppet government of Janos Kadar, that has been put into place after the revolution, got a considerable amount of freedoms in economic planning, and later on even in the political course it has chosen to follow.
Consequently,
today Hungary enjoys more economic welfare and also more liberal policies and human rights than the other communist countries do.
The fact that all the refugees, practically all the refugees of the 1956 revolution,
received amnesty and are free to go back to Hungary and visit.
And the Hungarian press refers to the revolution of 1956 less and less as to a counter-revolution, but more and more as to the terrible events of October 1956, shows that they really don't want to
hold up this as a threat or a record against any one of those participants who fled to the West.
So the climate has changed in the 60s, about a decade after the revolution, the system has relaxed and accomplished quite a turnaround.
Whether or not this is
really very good for the country, Solzhenitsyn probably would disagree because I think while welfare was established the soul was lost.
Today my contemporaries in Hungary wouldn't want to see another revolution if they can help it.
They have learned their lesson because there was an awful lot of suffering coming out of the revolution itself and they cherish
the little advantage they have managed to obtain at the price of the bloodshed in 1956.
So, a new Hungary came about which is more cynical, less idealistic and totally resigned to the Soviet dominion.
So, in a way, the Soviets have established themselves forever in the aftermath

But we gained little freedoms that we cherish, and we will think it over twice before we say anything dirty against the Soviets in big publicity, while we are allowed not to say anything about the Soviet in our private circles.
Okay.
Now that you've lived in the United States for about 20 years, how do you see certain things such as the Cold War, the Red Scare feeling in the United States during that?
Well, I think I have a double feeling.
Basically, I am concerned about both the dumb, shortsighted, uninformed rhetoric of the ultraconservative right wing, which tries to artificially keep up the Red Scare without having intelligent
propaganda to offer, because basically the rhetoric goes without any solid information.
On the other hand, the liberal movements that try to downplay the Red Scare are just as short-sighted and uninformed.

so I feel that the basic facts of life are that this country remains isolated in in terms of information and perspective from the rest of the world and as a consequence we do not have a public opinion that is realistic about our place and role in worldwide dimensions one of the

typical things that I might quote is the fact that even our diplomats in the Soviet Union do not speak Russian, and our general public keeps on being geographically and historically ignorant about the past, about dangers of the present, and about the nature of the Soviet, of the communist movement.

So you either have one kind of propaganda or another, but there is no core of well-informed, thoughtful, intelligent people who would responsibly build a public opinion that is realistic and bases the decisions on facts rather than feelings and immediate selfish interests.
A lot of politicians
use the writing rhetoric in order to win votes, rather than any other purpose.
So I'm a little bit discouraged, but I must say I got used to it.
I do not expect people to know the facts of history, or even the facts of geography.
So what
the Soviet empire really is, what problems it has, and how it really relates to its own internal problems.
We have a lot of tasks to educate the public, but I don't see the people really involved in doing it.
Very quickly, could you describe what you think the Soviet Union is?
Well, I think the Soviet Union carries an awful lot of internal problems with it, but we should not rejoice
and say that it will destroy itself on that account.
I think, on the one hand, we must see that the Soviet is a system loaded with problems.
On the other hand, the problems that the Soviets have make them even more aggressive rather than less ready to strike out and risk confrontation and even war with us.

And this we do not easily understand because we think that if we have economic problems, for example, then we are less interested in spending on defense and we are more interested in spending on our own problems and solve our own problems.
All those, the logic of the Soviet is exactly the reverse of what, of the logic by which this country lives.
And I think most of our mistakes come from the fact that we don't realize that the system has a different internal logic.
I think that the Soviets are a constant threat to the rest of the world, and also to this country.
However, that doesn't mean that their system is superior.
Their system is running into more and more problems.
As a consequence, they are even more tempted to
take the risks of large confrontations in order to get out of their problems by, you might say, robbing other countries.
Okay.
Also, there was a, it's a situation that ran vaguely similar, the situation in Vietnam, which there was a war, I suppose, against communism.
but specifically, how do you feel about the large influx of refugees coming to the United States after you've seen the large influx of Hungarians coming to the United States?
Well, I think one has to be open and helpful to the people who are in need, and that I say on a general scale as a conviction.
I think
especially the Vietnamese refugees, had the right even to be helped by America more than the Hungarian refugees had the right to be helped.
There is some parallelism, though, because I think in both cases, the tragedy that has taken place involved the United States one way or another.
In Vietnam, I think the United States was much more involved than in Hungary.
Of course, do not think that as a consequence, you know, anybody at any time wanting to come to this country should be given a free ticket.
But, of course, the country is still wrestling with its own identity and in defining its own policies of immigration.
This is a country of people who themselves are the descendants of immigrants,
and therefore it would be very difficult to close the borders to further immigrants if we are ourselves immigrants or the grandchildren or great-grandchildren of immigrants.
So it's, yeah, there is a moral question here, also a long-range policy setting and an assessment of the resources of the country.
And I really don't know where the limits should be placed.
Okay.
Father Denis, how do you feel that the United States should react now and in the near future?
to or should handle its self-diplomacy with the Soviet satellites, Hungary and those countries in the Soviet Union itself?
I may not really.
I probably have stopped thinking about how this country should operate.
In the last 20 years, I became cynical enough to
wonder only how it is going to operate.
I think it will operate according to its perceived interests, rather than any lofty principles of any sort.
I don't see anything wrong with you following your own principles, I just wish that those principles would be a little more far-sighted.
At the present time,

the United States is still involved in a scheme that came about in the Kennedy years namely cooperation coexistence and hope for loosening of the Soviet system by economic and cultural cultural exchange I don't think that this will change unless the Soviets unless the Soviet changes its mind in other words we will give
foreign aid, loan, help of any sort, to the extent we can do business with them.
There are, I simply see, no possibility for this country to change its course.
I mean, the most blatant case was the grains sale.
We are selling grain to the Soviet Union, not because we are merciful to the hungry people there,
but because otherwise our farmers will be upset.
As a consequence, we will do business with that part of the country as long as we can do profitably business with them.
I think that this is not necessarily a bad policy, but, well, this also means that there is no way for us to keep the
to change the situation of the world over there in any significant way.
I may not admire this country for what has taken place in the last 20 years, and yet, at the same time, I say, well, maybe we have eased the brutality of
of the Soviet system to some extent in some countries, like Hungary itself, which received a lot of financial and other aid from the United States through an increase of foreign exchange.
I don't know.
I don't see any solution for these great problems of the world.
I think we are living in the, living out the consequences of what has taken place after the Second World War.
And I don't think anybody knows how to solve the problems, realistically.
I am of the conviction that the present system of
of defeat and problems is better than a nuclear war.
As a consequence, I certainly would not say that we should inch our way to a nuclear confrontation.
I would like to see this country being more willing to make sacrifices for the freedom it possesses.

and be less blatantly selfish and hedonistic in just trying to do everything in order to improve its living standard I feel that we have gotten into a mentality that might cost our most precious freedom one of these days but how can this logic be changed we are sort of slipping into a mentality in which

even the most conservative, Republican, right-wing elements in this country would make a decision in favor of the economy as the first priority, regardless of any worldwide consequences for the future of freedom.
That seems to be the most discouraging.
uh, aspect of, of our present mentality that we have established.
And I don't think that, uh, even, even Reagan has a different mind.
Okay.
Thank you, Father Dennis.
I appreciate it.
I enjoyed this.
